newsitem.title: UK: INTERVIEW-Dorling hit by US retail woes.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW-Dorling hit by US retail woes.

text.p: Difficult conditions in the U.S. retail book market have forced British publisher Dorling Kindersley Holdings Plc to issue a profit warning, group managing director Rod Hare said on Tuesday.
"The primary factor for the downgrade in the profit forecast is...the U.S. book market has not performed as expected," Hare told Reuters in a telephone interview.

Dorling said earlier that full year profits would be lower than those of last year. The company restated pre-tax profit for the year to June 30 1996 as 12.9 million stg rather than 17.4 million to reflect a change in accounting policy in respect of multimedia development costs.
Hare said that Dorling had also been hurt by the strength of sterling against the dollar, which he said would result in "well over a million pounds of lost profit".

The full-year performance will also take a hit from a decision to increase investment in the DK Family Learning direct selling business, which operates in Britain and the U.S. and the new markets of Australia and Russia.

Hare said that Dorling had suffered from a change in policy at U.S. book retail chains Borders and Barnes & Noble, which had cleared out their stock and cut new orders after their store expansion programmes slowed.

Hare said that Dorling believed a more normal re-order pattern would be restored from the spring onwards for back order books, However, he expects the major U.S. chains to continue to order less initial stock of new titles.
The company plans to expand its direct selling business into India, New Zealand, South Africa, Mexico and maybe Singapore.
Hare said the launch of direct selling in Russia and Australia had required investment of around one million stg in each of those markets.
However, he said the push into the other new markets would not be as costly as the plans for South Africa and Singapore involved only scaled-down operations.
